content: Imperial College aims to provide comfortable, safe, and affordable on-campus accommodation for all first-year undergraduates. The university owns and operates its own halls to ensure high-quality facilities and support services. Rents for first-year undergraduate halls are set to be competitive with similar accommodation in the local market and at other comparable London universities, with the goal of breaking even rather than making a surplus. This approach allows the university to renew and maintain the first-year undergraduate accommodation portfolio for future generations of students.

metadata.title: Accommodation vision
key_points: Imperial provides on-campus accommodation for all first-year undergraduates
Halls are owned and operated by the university to ensure quality
Rents are set to be competitive and to cover costs, not make a profit

content: Imperial College is dedicated to providing high-quality service to students. If you have feedback, whether a suggestion, compliment, or complaint, we want to hear it. We aim to listen carefully, respond promptly and politely, provide explanations or apologies, keep you updated, and be open and honest. Most issues can be resolved informally with the staff or team involved. For unresolved complaints, you can escalate to the Village Manager, Student Accommodation Office Manager, Head of Residential Services, or Director of Campus Services. The Imperial College Students' Union can also provide advice and representation. We are committed to the Student Accommodation Code of Practice, and you can contact the Office of the Independent Adjudicator if you are still unsatisfied.

content: Imperial College London's student accommodation has robust fire safety measures in place, including automatic fire detection, alarms, regular audits, and 24/7 trained staff response. Residents must adhere to fire safety guidelines, such as not tampering with equipment, familiarizing themselves with emergency escape routes, and keeping fire doors closed. Failure to comply can result in prosecution and fines. Personal Emergency Evacuation Plans (PEEPs) are available for residents with mobility or sensory impairments. To prevent false alarms, residents should take precautions like using kitchen windows to dissipate smoke, avoiding open flames, and closing doors when showering.

content: Current residents must manage waste and recycling responsibly. Glass bottles, cans, tins, hard plastics, paper, card, and food can be recycled. Proper recycling reduces environmental impact and fire hazards. Rinsing items before recycling helps maintain quality. Coated paper/card cannot be recycled. The system has green bins for recyclables and black bins for waste, with additional glass/paper/card segregation on campus. Some halls compost food waste. Reducing waste, reusing items, and recycling are encouraged. Unwanted clothes/shoes can be donated. An end-of-year reuse scheme in halls diverts items to good causes.

content: The Sustainable Halls Campaign at Imperial College London encourages students living in halls to take personal action against the climate crisis. Through the campaign, students can learn about sustainability, act on sustainability tips, and lead by volunteering as campaign volunteers. The hall that engages the most with the campaign can win a £250 prize for their chosen charity. Last year, the campaign reached 82,600 students who saved 860,000kWh of electricity, equivalent to powering a lightbulb for over 6,500 years. To get involved, students can enter a competition to win a £25 voucher and sign up to be a volunteer in their hall.

content: The college provides a Rent Guarantee Scheme for Imperial College undergraduate students who require a UK-based guarantor to secure private accommodation. The scheme covers rent up to £275 per week for a 12-month period, and is not available to postgraduate students. Eligibility criteria include being a full-time registered student with no outstanding debts, providing a satisfactory accommodation reference, and demonstrating the ability to pay rent. The application process involves uploading required documentation, paying an admin fee, and signing agreements with the landlord. The college does not sign any external paperwork or contracts, and the guarantee is limited to 12 months, with the option to renew if the contract is longer.

It also covers what happens when a tenancy agreement is entered into or if either the tenant or landlord changes their mind.

content: Landlords and tenants both have obligations to check legal requirements for providing or receiving accommodation. Landlords must check the immigration status of prospective tenants, and tenants should verify the legal property owner. Properties with three or more unrelated people sharing facilities (HMOs) may require a license, and landlords operating an HMO without a license can face prosecution. Tenants should report unlicensed HMOs to the local council.

content: Silwood Park is a postgraduate campus of Imperial College London, located in Ascot, Berkshire. It offers a range of accommodation options, including single, double, and studio rooms, as well as one-bedroom flats. The campus provides modern facilities for research and teaching in ecology, evolution, and conservation, set in a 100-hectare parkland. Students studying at Silwood Park can choose from five separate halls of residence: Brian Flowers, John Smith, Southwood, William Penney, and Mary Flowers. Due to ongoing refurbishment, some students may need to relocate within Silwood Park. The campus is not available for students studying at the London campuses.

content: Helen Kemp Porter, born in 1899, was a British-Belgian scientist who had a distinguished career at Imperial College London. She excelled in science from a young age, despite coming from a financially-straitened background, and went on to become Imperial's first female professor in 1959. Her pioneering work on plant metabolism and her election to the Royal Society in 1956 cemented her reputation as a leading scientist in her field. She was described as a caring, hardworking, and meticulous mentor who brought out the best in her students and colleagues.

content: Imperial College London guarantees accommodation for all first-year undergraduates, Oxbridge Medics, and students on official exchanges, if they meet certain terms and conditions. These include accepting an offer, submitting an accommodation application by a certain deadline, and being a full-time student for the full academic year. While preferences are considered, the College cannot guarantee a specific preference. Other students, such as those with insurance/clearing offers, intercalated BSc Medicine students, and postgraduate students, are not guaranteed accommodation but may be considered for any remaining vacancies. Under-18 students will be allocated a single room due to guidelines.

content: Prospective students may be allocated to twin rooms in Imperial College London's halls, which can be a more affordable option. While most rooms are single, twin rooms offer the potential to make new friends and have a study buddy. Sharing a room requires a tolerant and accepting attitude, flexibility, and respect for each other's possessions and personal space. Students can request to share a room with a friend during the application process. Twin room prices are generally cheaper than single rooms, and rooms with restricted views (RV) are even more affordable.
